script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I’ve been wrestling with a mystery that’s been nagging at me. In Moses 1, God reveals Himself to Moses in a way that’s absolutely staggering, calling him 'my son' in verse 4. But then, just a few verses later in Moses 1:12, Satan comes along and tries to completely unravel that identity. What’s really going on here, and why does this clash over identity feel like the key to unlocking everything?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, you’ve hit on something profound. This isn’t just a personal moment for Moses; it’s a cosmic battle over identity that echoes through every dispensation. Notice how God affirms Moses with, 'Behold, thou art my son' in Moses 1:4, and then Satan counters with doubt, saying, 'Moses, son of man, worship me' in verse 12. This is the first layer of a pattern that reveals how the adversary always targets our divine identity to derail God’s plan.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, so you’re saying this isn’t just about Moses? This identity struggle is something bigger, something we’re all part of? I need to understand how this connects across time.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, Sarah. Let’s frame this from multiple angles. First, in Moses’s time, this is about establishing his role as a prophet to lead Israel. Then, fast forward to Christ’s ministry—think of His temptations in Matthew 4:1-11, where Satan challenges His identity with 'If thou be the Son of God.' And today, as President Russell M. Nelson taught in his 2022 devotional 'Choices for Eternity,' our identity as children of God shapes every decision we make. This is a battle that spans eternity.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s fascinating, but how does this play out across dispensations? I mean, is there a thread that ties Moses’s experience to Abraham, or even to us in the modern Church?

script.speaker: David
script.text: There absolutely is. Let’s trace this theme of divine identity. Start with Moses in Moses 1:4-6, where God not only calls him 'my son' but also says, 'thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten.' Then, look at Abraham 3:22-23, where Abraham sees the noble and great spirits, including himself, chosen before the world was. This pattern of God affirming our premortal worth continues in the Doctrine and Covenants, like in section 76:24, where we’re described as 'begotten sons and daughters unto God.' It’s a consistent divine message across time.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’m starting to see it! Each time, God is reinforcing who we are before the challenges come. But what’s the purpose behind this pattern? Why does identity matter so much?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s where it gets powerful. God’s work, as He tells Moses in Moses 1:39, is 'to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' Our identity as His children is the foundation of that work. If we forget who we are, as Satan wants, we can’t fulfill our role in the plan of salvation. This is why every prophet, from Moses to Joseph Smith, has to rediscover and defend this truth.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s remarkable. So, our identity isn’t just a label—it’s tied directly to God’s eternal purpose. Let’s dive into some historical context. What do we know about Moses’s world that makes this identity revelation even more striking?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question. In Moses’s era, around the 13th or 14th century BC, the ancient Near Eastern cultures often viewed gods as distant, capricious beings who used humans as pawns. The idea of a personal, familial relationship with deity—like God calling Moses 'my son'—would have been radical. Archaeological findings, like ancient Egyptian texts, show their pharaohs were considered divine, but only as rulers, not as beloved children. This makes God’s intimate language in Moses 1:4 a complete paradigm shift for that time.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wow, so Moses isn’t just receiving a personal affirmation—he’s getting a cultural earthquake. That must have been mind-blowing for him. But let’s go back to that initial mystery. Why does Satan target identity so aggressively, and how does Moses ultimately overcome it?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Let’s unpack that. Satan’s strategy in Moses 1:12 is to strip away the divine connection by reducing Moses to 'son of man,' a mere mortal. He’s trying to erase the eternal perspective God just gave him. But Moses overcomes this by clinging to what he knows—saying in verse 13, 'Who art thou? For behold, I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten.' It’s his reaffirmed identity, coupled with calling on God’s power in verse 20, that finally drives Satan away.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so powerful. Moses doesn’t just resist—he reclaims his identity as a weapon. I’m curious, though—are there hidden connections here to other scriptures that most people might miss?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely, Sarah. Notice how Moses’s response mirrors Christ’s in Matthew 4:10, where Jesus rebukes Satan with 'Get thee hence, Satan.' Both rely on their divine identity and authority. Then, connect this to Abraham 3:27, where the Lord asks, 'Whom shall I send?' and Christ answers, 'Here am I, send me.' It’s the same pattern—identity as the foundation for mission. And in the Doctrine and Covenants 93:29, we learn 'man was also in the beginning with God,' reinforcing that our identity predates mortality.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never saw those links before! It’s like a web of divine identity woven through all scripture. How does this tie into the premortal life we read about in Abraham 3?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It’s the origin story of our identity. In Abraham 3:22-23, we see that we were spirits 'before the world was,' and some were chosen for specific roles. This isn’t just history—it’s purpose. Knowing we existed with God before birth, as these verses teach, changes how we see every trial and choice on earth. It’s why Satan’s counterfeit in Moses 1 fails; he can’t erase what’s eternal.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s stunning. So, our premortal identity isn’t just a footnote—it’s the bedrock of why we’re here. Let’s shift to how this applies today. How does understanding this help us in our modern lives?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It’s everything, Sarah. President Nelson’s teaching in 'Choices for Eternity' emphasizes that knowing we’re children of God affects every decision. When we face doubts or temptations, like Moses did, we can stand firm by remembering who we are. It’s not just about resisting Satan—it’s about choosing to align with our divine destiny, whether in small daily choices or life-altering ones.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that. It’s like we’re equipped with the same power Moses had, just in a modern context. What’s one practical way we can hold onto this identity when life gets tough?

script.speaker: David
script.text: One way is to echo Moses’s actions in Moses 1:18, where he calls upon God after resisting Satan. Prayer reconnects us to our divine source. Also, studying scriptures like Abraham 3 reminds us of our premortal purpose. It’s a constant anchor, no matter the storm.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so actionable. Before we wrap up, I’m curious—how can teachers or parents use these insights to help others grasp their divine identity?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’d suggest starting with simple, tangible activities, like those in the Come Follow Me manual. For kids, have them look in a mirror and say, 'I am a child of God,' as suggested for teaching Moses 1:4. For older students, guide them to trace the identity theme across Moses 1, Abraham 3, and modern prophetic teachings. It’s about making the eternal personal.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s beautiful, David. I feel like we’ve uncovered something transformative today. As we close, I want to invite our listeners to take a moment this week to reflect on Moses 1:4 and Abraham 3:23. Ask yourself, how does knowing I’m a child of God change how I see myself and others?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’ll add to that, Sarah. Ponder God’s words in Moses 1:39 about His work and glory. Let that purpose sink in, and see how it shapes your choices. We’ve only scratched the surface of these truths, but they can guide us every day.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Thank you, David, for walking us through this profound journey. Listeners, join us next time as we continue to explore the scriptures together. Until then, keep seeking those divine connections.
